description:
Macrophomina phaseolina MS6 is a fungal species that belongs to the phylum Ascomycota. It is a plant pathogen known to cause charcoal rot disease in a wide range of crops, including soybeans, corn, and sunflowers.

The MS6 strain of M. phaseolina is a filamentous fungus that produces dark-colored, thick-walled resting structures called sclerotia. These sclerotia can survive in the soil for extended periods, even in the absence of a host plant, and serve as the primary mode of infection and dispersal for the fungus.

The fungus penetrates the plant's roots and colonizes the vascular system, disrupting the flow of water and nutrients. This leads to the development of symptoms such as wilting, stunting, and premature senescence of the affected plants.

M. phaseolina MS6 has been extensively studied due to its significant impact on agricultural production. Researchers have focused on understanding its biology, epidemiology, and developing effective management strategies to mitigate the damage caused by this pathogen.
